metadata.case_name: Board of Trustees, Ayurvedic and Unani Tibbia College, Delhi v. State of Delhi

facts.text: Hakim Mohammad Ajmal Khan started Hindustani Dawakhana in 1903 and established Tibbia College. He died in 1927.

In 1911, Hakim Mohammad Ajmal Khan and others formed Anjuman-i-Tibbia, registered under Societies Registration Act, 1860. Name changed to Board of Trustees, Ayurvedic and Unani Tibbia College, Delhi in 1915.

Board ran Tibbia College, attached hostel, and pharmaceutical institute. Rules provided for max 35 trustees, one-third Hakims and Vaids, annual subscription Rs.12/-, vacancy on non-payment, Managing Committee of 9 members +6 officials for 3 years, office-bearers elected for 3 years, Secretary preferably lineal descendant of Hakim Ajmal Khan.
Hakim Mohammad Jamil Khan, son of Hakim Ajmal Khan and petitioner No.2, was first Secretary.

In 1948, Rameshwar Dayal (Collector Delhi), Dr. Yudhvir Singh (President Delhi Municipal Committee) and others elected members. Dr. Yudhvir Singh elected President, Mool Chand Gagerna Joint Secretary.
Struggle between groups for control of Board, college, and Hindustani Dawakhana. Criminal proceedings followed.

On October 18, 1949, suit filed in court of Senior Subordinate Judge, Delhi under S.92 CPC against Secretary and 31 members. On October 19, 1949, two advocates appointed joint receivers with plenary powers, took possession of Dawakhana and college between Oct 19-23, 1949.
Delhi State Legislature passed Tibbia College Act, 1952 (Delhi Act 5 of 1952) on October 10, 1952. S.9 dissolved old Board, vested property in new Tibia Delhi College Board.
Suit withdrawn after Act. Application to hand over possession to new Board allowed despite objection by petitioner No.1. Petitioner No.1 unsuccessfully moved Punjab High Court.
Petitioner No.1 moved Supreme Court under Art.32 to restrain enforcement of Act. Respondents raised preliminary objections. Petition withdrawn on December 13, 1954.
Amendments to Board rules. Fresh election held January 6, 1955 per amended rules. Managing Committee resolution January 11, 1955 authorizing Secretary to file petition.
Present petition filed March 14, 1955, amended to add petitioner No.2 and new grounds.
Respondents' preliminary objection: Members ceased to be members in 1950-51 for non-payment of subscription, 1955 elections ineffective, Board ceased to exist.
Affidavits and cash books (Ex.B series 1951-1954) on subscription payments disputed, especially 1949-50, 1950-51. Petitioner No.2 and others claimed paid to Financial Secretary.
Court decided not to resolve disputed facts on affidavits, proceeded to constitutional validity.

legal_issues.text: Whether Delhi State Legislature had legislative competence to enact Tibbia College Act, 1952, as old Board was a corporation with objects not confined to one State, falling under Entry 44 List I.
Whether impugned Act violates Arts. 14, 19(1)(f), 31 of Constitution.
Whether impugned Act overrides Societies Registration Act, 1860 (Central Act) under S.22 Government of Part C States Act, 1951.
Whether impugned Act is colourable legislation due to mala fides.

petitioner_arguments.text: Delhi Legislature lacked competence as old Board was corporation (registered under Societies Act), objects not confined to Delhi (Entry 32 List II), falls under Entry 44 List I.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 32 List II, Entry 44 List I, S.21 Government of Part C States Act 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Act violates Art.14 (arbitrary, no reasonable classification, other mismanaged institutions not targeted), Art.19(1)(f) (right to property), Art.31 (acquisition without compensation).
Act overrides Central Societies Registration Act, 1860, repugnant under S.22 Government of Part C States Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Societies Registration Act 1860, S.22 Government of Part C States Act 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Old Board not a corporation, unincorporated society under second part Entry 32 List II. Objects confined to Delhi. Alternatively, supportable under Entry 11 List II (Education), Entry 28 List III (Charities).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 32 List II, Entry 11 List II, Entry 28 List III

respondent_arguments.text: Gross mismanagement: student strikes, defalcation, interruptions in 1949. No other similar institutions named. Single society can be class by itself.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14, Chiranjit Lal Chowdhuri v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: No violation Art.31(2) as no compulsory acquisition. Art.19(1)(f) not applicable post-dissolution per S.14 Societies Act. Members had no beneficial interest.
Members ceased membership 1950-51 for non-payment, no locus.

court_reasoning.text: Society registered under Societies Registration Act 1860 is not a corporation; provisions (Ss.5-8,13-14) confer privileges but no intention to incorporate; property vests in trustees/governing body; analogous to Trade Unions/Friendly Societies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unincorporated society falls under second part Entry 32 List II.

court_reasoning.text: New Board incorporated but powers/duties confined to Delhi institutions (S.3,7,9 Tibbia Act); old Board rights vest for new Board's purposes only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Impugned Act within Entry 32 List II (dissolution unincorporated society, incorporation new body confined to State).

court_reasoning.text: No Art.14 violation: no other similar institutions shown; single society exceptional features sufficient.
No Art.31(2) as no acquisition, mere transfer of management. Art.31(1) valid if law competent. Art.19(1)(f): members no property right per S.14 Societies Act; no beneficial interest on dissolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to choose successor society not 'property' under Art.19(1)(f).

court_reasoning.text: S.22 Govt Part C States Act inapplicable: Societies Act 1860 not Parliament law post-Constitution.
No colourable legislation: competence exists, motives irrelevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: K.C. Gajapathi Narayan Deo v. State of Orissa.

holdings.text: Society under Societies Registration Act 1860 is unincorporated, under Entry 32 List II. Tibbia College Act 1952 within Delhi Legislature competence.
No repugnancy with Societies Registration Act 1860.

precedents_cited.case_name: Taff Vale Railway v. Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants
precedents_cited.relevance: Registered trade union not incorporated; property held by trustees.
Registered trade union not juristic person distinct from members.

precedents_cited.case_name: Servants of India Society v. Charity Commissioner Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Societies Act societies unincorporated under Entry 32 List II.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chiranjit Lal Chowdhuri v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Single corporation/society can be class for legislation under Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.C. Gajapathi Narayan Deo v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Colourable legislation turns on competence, not motives.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Affected vested property right, unlike here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarkadas Srinivas v. Sholapur Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Shareholder rights continued, unlike dissolution here.

statutes_cited.name: Societies Registration Act, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Registers unincorporated societies; no incorporation; property vests in governing body; dissolution rules.

statutes_cited.name: Tibbia College Act, 1952 (Delhi Act 5 of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: Dissolves old Board, creates new corporate Board confined to Delhi college/institute, transfers property for new purposes.

statutes_cited.name: Government of Part C States Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Delhi Legislature powers limited to Lists II/III; repugnancy with Parliament laws.

outcome.summary: Writ petition challenging constitutional validity of Tibbia College Act, 1952 dismissed. Act held within legislative competence of Delhi Legislature; no violation of Arts.14,19,31. No repugnancy or colourable legislation.

key_quotes.text: A corporation aggregate has been defined as a collection of individuals united into one body under a special denomination, having perpetual succession under an artificial form...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines corporation; distinguishes from registered society.

key_quotes.text: On registration under the Societies Registration Act, the old Board did not become a corporation... it remained and continued to be an unincorporated society.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The right to determine the body which shall administer the funds or property of the dissolved society... is not a right of property within the meaning of Art.19(1)(f).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: If the legislature is competent to pass a particular law, the motives which impelled it to act are really irrelevant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
